Title: Siematic Mobelwerke GmbH & Co. KG v. Siematic Corp.

Title: Lewis v. Frazao Bldg. Corp.
Court: Appellate Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: The instrumentality test for piercing the corporate veil requires proof of three elements: (1) control, not mere majority or complete stock control, but complete domination, not only of finances but of policy and business practice in respect to the transaction attacked so that the corporate entity as to this transaction had at the time no separate mind, will or existence of its own, (2) that such control must have been used by the defendant to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of a statutory or other positive legal duty, or a dishonest or unjust act in contravention of plaintiff's legal rights, and (3) that the aforesaid control and breach of duty must proximately cause the injury or unjust loss complained of.

Title: Thrift Drug, Inc. v. Universal Prescription Adm'rs
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Second Circuit.
Headnote: To pierce corporate veil under New York law, it must be shown (i) that owner exercised complete domination over corporation with respect to transaction at issue; and (ii) that such domination was used to commit fraud or wrong that injured the party seeking to pierce veil.
Document Preview: Pharmacy sued prescription benefits plan administrator and administrator's sole shareholder for breach of contract, alleging that defendants failed to reimburse pharmacy for dispensed prescriptions.  The United States District Court for the Southern District of New York, Whitman Knapp, J., 890 F.Supp. 319, granted summary judgment for pharmacy, and held that pharmacy could pierce administrator's corporate veil to reach shareholder's personal assets. Administrator and shareholder appealed.  The Court of Appeals held that: (1) district court's findings with respect to piercing of corporate veil were insufficient; (2) pharmacy showed that it timely submitted claims to administrator; and (3) ERISA did not preempt action. Affirmed in part, vacated and remanded in part.

Title: Trans-World Intern., Inc. v. Smith-Hemion Productions, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, C.D. California.
Headnote: Fraud is not essential element of alter ego claim under either California or Delaware law; while fraud is factor to be considered, absence of fraud is not dispositive.
Document Preview: Production company sued musical performers in family group and performers' corporation, alleging promissory estoppel, fraud, and alter ego claims arising out of cancelled televised performance.  After mistrial, plaintiff dismissed fraud claim and parties submitted claims to court based on record created during trial.  The District Court, Laughlin E. Waters, Senior District Judge, held that: (1) production company failed to establish promissory estoppel claim against performer who stated intent to appear on show; (2) dismissal of fraud claim did not preclude alter ego claims; and (3) performers were not alter egos of corporation. So ordered.

Title: Garcia v. Coffman
Court: Court of Appeals of New Mexico.
Headnote: Misrepresentation of corporation's assets and purposes is but one species of improper purpose sufficient to support piercing of corporate veil; other varieties of improper purposes include participation or direction of improper activities and joint improper acts, such as when party and subservient corporation cooperate to perform series of actions which, if all such actions were performed by either alone, would create liability.
Document Preview: Patient sued chiropractor and his corporation, alleging scheme to provide excessive services and charge excessive fees.  The District Court, Bernalillo County, Susan M. Conway, D.J., awarded nominal damages and punitive damages for fraudulent misrepresentation and breach of fiduciary duty, and awarded attorney fees.  Appeal was taken.  The Court of Appeals, Flores, J., held that: (1) patient could pierce corporate veil and recover directly from chiropractor; (2) patient could not recover for both breach of fiduciary duty and fraudulent misrepresentation; (3) punitive damages were recoverable; and (4) attorney fees were recoverable. Affirmed in part; reversed ion part. Hartz, C.J., concurred specially and filed opinion.

Court: United States District Court, D. Connecticut.
Headnote: Under federal maritime law, plaintiff seeking to pierce corporate veil must prove either that individual defendant used his or her corporation to perpetrate fraud, or that individual defendant so dominated corporation and disregarded its corporate form that corporation primarily transacted individual defendant's personal business rather than its own corporate business.
Document Preview: Company brought action against individual principals of large group of shipping companies, and against shipping and real estate entities created by such principals, seeking to collect arbitration award for breach of sub-charter agreement.  The District Court, Goettel, J., held that: (1) evidence was sufficient to conclude that principals dominated their companies and disregarded their corporate forms, as required to pierce corporate veil; (2) bad faith breach of contract claim was barred by res judicata; (3) plaintiff could not prevail on fraudulent nondisclosure claim; (4) plaintiff was entitled to recover on claim alleging conspiracy to fraudulently transfer mortgage; but (5) plaintiff could not establish claims for conspiracy to defraud against individuals and partnerships who were alter egos of other alleged participants in conspiracy. Ordered accordingly.

Headnote: Under Montana law, courts generally consider two factors in determining whether to disregard separate identity of corporation; first, party seeking to pierce corporate veil must show corporation is alter ego of individual, and second, there must be showing that corporate entity was used as subterfuge to defeat public convenience, justify wrong, or perpetrate fraud.
Document Preview: Taxpayer brought wrongful levy action against United States after United States levied on antique automobiles that were titled in name of nonprofit charitable corporation to satisfy taxpayer's liabilities. The Court of Appeals, Alarcon, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) under Montana law, United States was entitled to use reversing piercing of the corporate veil theory to find existence of alter ego relationship; (2) under Montana law, no finding of fraud was required before United States levied upon automobiles; and (3) federal district court did not abuse its discretion in denying motion to allow testimony from taxpayer's attorney. Affirmed. Beezer, Circuit Judge, filed a dissenting opinion.

Headnote: For doctrine traditionally known as "piercing of the corporate veil" to apply, two requirements must be met: first, there must be unity of interest in ownership such that separate personalities of corporation and individual no longer exist; second, circumstances must be such that adherence to fiction of separate corporate existence would sanction fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: Former president of foreign corporation brought suit against individual shareholder/directors and corporation.  The Circuit Court, Cook County, Jerome Burke, J., quashed service of process on nonresident shareholder/directors for lack of personal jurisdiction. Former president appealed.  The Appellate Court, McNamara, J., held that: (1) former president failed to demonstrate that corporate veil should be pierced and individual nonresident shareholder/directors subjected to personal jurisdiction with respect to breach of contract claims; (2) individual nonresident shareholder/directors were not subject to personal jurisdiction through application of fiduciary shield doctrine; (3) personal jurisdiction did not exist over those defendants with respect to breach of fiduciary claim; (4) plaintiff failed to demonstrate existence of conspiracy to justify attributing alleged defamatory statements made by Illinois resident to nonresident...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Mid-Century Ins. Co. v. Gardner
Court: Court of Appeal, Third District, California.
Headnote: In deciding whether to pierce corporate veil, issue is not so much whether, for all purposes, the corporation is the alter ego of its stockholders or officers, or whether the very purpose of organization of corporation was to defraud plaintiff, but whether, in particular case presented and for particular purposes of such case, justice and equity can best be accomplished and fraud and unfairness defeated by disregard of distinct entity of corporate form.
Document Preview: Automobile insurer sued for declaratory judgment regarding coverage provided by policy.  The Superior Court, Sacramento County, Richard C. Creeggan, J., entered judgment in favor of insurer, and appeal was taken.  The Court of Appeal, Sparks, J., held that: (1) corporation's principal shareholder and chief executive officer was not owner of corporate vehicles, within meaning of exclusion from uninsured motorist coverage for owned vehicles not listed in policy; (2) corporate veil could not be pierced to permit insurer to treat corporate vehicles as vehicles of principal; and (3) other insurance exclusion could not be interpreted to preclude coverage. Reversed and remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Kinetic Instruments, Inc. v. Lares
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Corporate veil may be pierced either when defendant has used corporation to perpetrate fraud or simply when he has dominated corporation for his personal business.
Document Preview: Holder of patent for dental handpiece brought infringement action against officer of competitor corporation alleging that officer was personally liable for competitor's acts of infringement.  Officer moved to dismiss for lack of personal jurisdiction and improper venue.  The District Court, Sand, J., held that: (1) complaint alleged sufficient facts to enable New York to assert jurisdiction over officer, and (2) complaint made adequate prima facie showing that venue was proper. Motion denied.

Title: In re Shailam
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. New York.
Headnote: New York courts pierce corporate form only when form has been used to achieve fraud, or when corporation has been so dominated by individual and its separate identity so disregarded that it primarily transacted dominator's business rather than its own and can be called the other's alter ego.
Document Preview: Trustee objected to debtors' schedules claiming as exempt the debtors' interest in pension and Keogh plans valued at $421,000.  The Bankruptcy Court, Justin J. Mahoney, Chief Judge, held that: (1) ERISA does not preempt trustee in bankruptcy from raising argument that funds deposited into qualified ERISA plan are avoidable as fraudulent conveyances under New York law; (2) trustee failed to establish that debtor's transfer of large amount of funds to his professional corporation's defined benefit pension plan was with intent to perpetrate fraud upon creditors, and thus failed to satisfy requirements for piercing corporate veil under New York law; and (3) permitting trustee to avoid as fraudulent conveyances under New York law transfers by one debtor into defined benefit plan would violate antialienation provision of ERISA. Objections overruled.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: 111 Properties, Inc. v. Lassiter
Court: District Court of Appeal of Florida, Fourth District.
Headnote: Corporations are legal entities separate and distinct from persons comprising them; absent fraud, corporate veil is not pierced.
Document Preview: Vendor brought action against purchaser corporation and corporation's sole stockholder for breach of contract and fraud.  The Circuit Court, Palm Beach County, Thomas Johnson, J., entered judgment for plaintiff and defendants appealed.  The District Court of Appeal, Gunther, J., held that: (1) even if formation of corporation was subterfuge to conceal identity of purchaser from vendor, that was not ground for piercing corporate veil, and (2) purchaser corporation did not breach agreement to assist vendor in collecting back taxes and back rent from tenant where tenant was insolvent and any effort to collect would have been futile. Reversed and remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Goulding v. Ag-Re-Co, Inc.
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, First District, Second Division.
Headnote: It is possible to disregard corporate entity and impose liability on real parties in interest by using equitable doctrine of "piercing the corporate veil"; there must be unity of interest in ownership such that separate personalities of corporation and individual no longer exist, and circumstances such that adherence to fiction of separate corporate existence would sanction fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: Action was brought sounding in breach of contract, account stated, and quantum meruit.  Defendant filed petition for relief from default judgment entered against him.  The Circuit Court, Cook County, Charles Durham, J., denied motion, and defendant appealed.  The Appellate Court, Scariano, J., held that defendant established meritorious defense and due diligence and, thus, should have been granted relief from default judgment. Reversed and remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Foster Wheeler Energy Corp. v. Metropolitan Knox Solid Waste Authority, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Sixth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Tennessee law, corporate veil doctrine applies primarily to prevent fraud or other tortious wrongdoing.
Document Preview: Contractor sued city and county for breach of contract between contractor and solid waste authority, which was nonprofit corporation created jointly by city and county, neither of whom were equity owners in authority.  The United States District Court for the Eastern District of Tennessee, Robert Leon Jordan, J., denied defendants' motion to dismiss.  Defendants appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Contie, Senior Circuit Judge, held that: (1) corporate veil would not be pierced to hold city and county liable, and (2) Tennessee Interlocal Cooperation Act did not provide for liability of city and county. Reversed and remanded with instructions.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Boyle v. Jacor Communications, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Ohio, Western Division.
Headnote: Law of New York allows court to look beyond corporate form where necessary to prevent fraud or to achieve equity.
Document Preview: Former corporate officer and director filed suit against parent corporation, demanding payment and interest on note and consulting agreement with subsidiary.  On plaintiff's motion for summary judgment, the District Court, Spiegel, J., held that: (1) Ohio choice of law rules applied; (2) under New York law, parent corporation's ownership of all of subsidiary's stock did not justify piercing corporate veil, and fact that parent's checks had been used to make recent payments to plaintiff did not unequivocally establish that parent had assumed subsidiary's obligations; and (3) genuine issues of material fact, as to whether parent and subsidiary had operated in such a manner as to justify piercing corporate veil, precluded summary judgment. Motion denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Geyer v. Ingersoll Publications Co.
Court: Court of Chancery of Delaware, New Castle County.
Headnote: Court can pierce corporate veil where there is fraud, or where subsidiary is in fact a mere instrumentality or alter ego of its owner.
Document Preview: Corporate creditor filed suit against corporation and corporate director for their alleged fiduciary breaches and fraudulent conveyances.  On defendants' motion to dismiss for lack of personal jurisdiction and failure to state claim upon which relief could be granted, the Chancery Court, Chandler, Vice Chancellor, held that: (1) corporation is insolvent, such that corporate director will owe fiduciary duties to corporation's creditors, whenever it is insolvent in fact, though no statutory proceedings have been filed against it; (2) Delaware court's exercise of personal jurisdiction over nonresident director of Delaware corporation did not violate due process; and (3) allegations in creditor's complaint were sufficient to state claim against corporation under Fraudulent Conveyances Act. Motion denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: N.L.R.B. v. O'Neill
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Ninth Circuit.
Headnote: Court of Appeals examines three factors in determining whether to pierce corporate veil: amount of respect given to separate identity of corporation by its shareholders, degree of injustice visited upon litigants by recognition of corporate entity, and fraudulent intent of incorporators.
Document Preview: National Labor Relations Board (NLRB) petitioned for enforcement of two of its orders entered in connection with meat plant's closing, reopening and subsequent permanent closing. The Court of Appeals, D.W. Nelson, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) fraudulent concealment exception applied to toll running of limitations period applicable to unfair labor practice complaint until date unions received testimony of indicted company official that majority shareholder of original employer was heavily involved in new corporations operating plant and, thus, NLRB properly allowed reinstatement of previously dismissed charge; (2) NLRB's finding that corporations which took over operation of plant were alter egos of prior employer, so as to warrant treating them as single employer liable for unfair labor practices, was supported by evidence; and (3) piercing of corporate veil so as to hold majority shareholder liable for unfair labor practices was justified. Orders enforced.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Link v. Leadworks Corp.
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Eighth District, Cuyahoga County.
Headnote: Corporate fiction may be disregarded under alter ego doctrine when domination and control over corporation by those to be held liable is so complete that corporation has no separate mind, will, or existence of its own; that domination and control was used to commit fraud or wrong or other dishonest or unjust act; and injury or unjust loss resulted to plaintiff from such control and wrong.
Document Preview: SUCCESSOR LIABILITY - Continuation of Transferor. Whether transferee corporation was continuation of transferor was fact question.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1038 Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Swall v. Custom Automotive Services, Inc.
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Western District.
Headnote: To satisfy two-pronged test for determining whether corporate veil should be pierced, first, corporation must be controlled and influenced by persons or by another corporation, and, second, evidence must establish that corporate cloak was used as subterfuge to defeat public convenience, to justify wrong, or to perpetrate fraud.
Document Preview: President and vice president of corporation were held personally liable for corporate debt to consignor in the Clay County Circuit Court, Frank D. Connett, Jr., J., and president and vice president appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Ulrich, J., held that: (1) evidence was sufficient for finding that president and vice president dominated and controlled corporation as required for piercing corporate veil, and (2) evidence supported findings that corporation was undercapitalized and that president and vice president stripped corporation's assets in reckless disregard of consignor's legal rights as required for piercing corporate veil. Affirmed.

Court: United States District Court, N.D. California.
Headnote: Factors to consider in determining whether to pierce corporate veil are unity of interest and ownership between corporation and shareholder is such that the two no longer exist as separate entities, failure to disregard corporation would result in injustice, and fraudulent intent of a corporation to evade civil or criminal liability.
Document Preview: Union brought action against employer to recover contributions to pension and health and welfare funds.  On motion for summary judgment, the District Court, Caulfield, J., held that: (1) nonunion signatory business was alter ego of union-signatory; (2) corporate veil would be pierced to impose liability on individual shareholder; and (3) punitive damages in the amount of compensatory damages were appropriate. Judgment for plaintiffs.

Title: Summit-Top Development, Inc. v. Williamson Const., Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: Concept of piercing the corporate veil is applied to remedy injustices which arise where party has overextended his privilege in use of corporate entity in order to defeat justice, perpetrate fraud or to evade contractual or tort responsibility.
Document Preview: Contractor brought suit against developer and its principals to recover unpaid balances.  The Cobb State Court, Nix, J., awarded actual damages and special lien, and also rendered verdict against developer's principals personally.  Defendants appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Cooper, J., held that: (1) contractor's inclusion of nonlienable charges in original claim of lien did not preclude enforcement of lien; (2) contractor's cessation of work was not an abandonment of the contract; and (3) corporate veil was properly pierced. Affirmed.

Title: Gurnik v. Lee
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana, Second District.
Headnote: Courts are generally reluctant to disregard corporate entity, but will do so to protect innocent third parties from fraud or injustice.
Document Preview: Former travel agency president filed suit against travel agency and its shareholders to collect unpaid bonus.  The Superior Court,Marion County, Gerald S. Zore, J., entered partial summary judgment in favor of defendants and, after bench trial, entered judgment in favor of president against travel agency.  President appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Buchanan, J., held that: (1) bonus was wage in meaning of statute allowing treble damages and attorney fees award, and (2) merely loaning funds to travel agency by shareholders was not sufficient to justify piercing corporate veil. Affirmed in part, reversed in part, and remanded. Sullivan, J., dissented and filed opinion.

Title: United Elec. Contractors, Inc. v. Progress Builders, Inc.
Court: Appellate Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: Court may pierce corporate veil only under exceptional circumstances, for example, where corporation is mere shell, serving no legitimate purpose, and used primarily as intermediary to perpetuate fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: Electrical subcontractor brought suit to recover money owing for electrical work performed on construction project, as well as to set aside alleged fraudulent conveyance to wife of president of corporation that owned land.  The Superior Court, Judicial District of Waterbury, Pellegrino, J., entered judgment in favor of subcontractor on suit against corporations which owned property and which acted as general contractor on project, but refused to pierce corporate veil and to impose liability on either president or his wife.  Subcontractor appealed.  The Appellate Court, Norcott, J., held that: (1) president's wife was bound, no less than other defendants, by admission in answer, and (2) corporate veil should have been pierced to hold president personally liable on debt. Affirmed in part and reversed in part.

Title: Lawton v. Temple-Warren Ford, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: Separateness of corporation entity will be disregarded to remedy injustices which arise where party has overextended his privilege in use of corporate entity in order to perpetrate fraud or avoid total responsibility.

Title: Canario v. Lidelco, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Proper criteria in determining whether corporate veil should be pierced include absence of formalities found in normal corporate existence, inadequate capitalization, personal use of corporate funds, and perpetration of fraud by means of corporate vehicle.

Title: Bergman v. Nicholson Management and Consultants, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Fourth Circuit.
Headnote: Corporation will be disregarded and shareholder held liable where corporation is simply alter ego of shareholder; however, before corporate entity will be disregarded on that basis, proof of fraud or deceit, practiced by shareholder when acting for corporation, is usually required. LSA-R.S. 12:95.
Document Preview: Vendors of apartments and furnishings brought action against corporate buyer and its sole shareholder which had guaranteed notes given in connection with sale to enforce mortgage and for money judgment for corporate waste and for past-due rent.  Claims were consolidated and the Civil District Court, Parish of Orleans, Louis A. DiRosa, J., denied claim for waste of property against sole shareholder and denied claim against sole shareholder on continuing guaranty.  Vendors appealed.  The Court of Appeal, Williams, J., held that: (1) when sole shareholder as guarantor paid total sum due after primary obligor's notice to vendors that it was unable to timely pay balance due under note but before vendors made forced collection on it, payment satisfied shareholder's obligation to vendors, and (2) sole owner could not be held liable for corporate waste of property. Affirmed. Schott, C.J., and Armstrong, J., concurred in the result.

Title: Jones v. Briley
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, First Circuit.
Headnote: Corporate veil may be pierced under two exceptional circumstances: where shareholders acting through the corporation commit fraud or deceit on a third party; and where shareholders fail to conduct the business on a corporate footing, disregarding the corporate entity to such extent that they and it become indistinguishable.
Document Preview: Parents of boy injured in hunting accident at camp operated by hunting club, a nonprofit corporation, sued, inter alia, members of the club not involved in the accident.  Motion of such members for partial summary judgment was granted by the Twenty-First Judicial District Court, Parish of St. Helena, Edward B. DuFreche, J., and plaintiffs appealed.  The Court of Appeal, Gonzales, J., held that: (1) failure to observe various corporate formalities did not warrant piercing the corporate veil, and (2) if there was duty on part of the corporation to make and enforce safety rules, existence of such group duty would not result in individual liability for the corporation members. Affirmed. Lottinger, J., concurred in the result.

Title: Riggins v. Dixie Shoring Co., Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Louisiana.
Headnote: Courts are reluctant to hold a shareholder, officer, or director of a corporation personally liable for corporate obligations, in absence of fraud, malfeasance, or criminal wrongdoing. LSA-R.S. 12:93, subd. B.

Title: Crabtree v. Tristar Automotive Group, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, to pierce corporate veil, there must be a showing of absence of corporate formalities, inadequate capitalization, personal use of corporate funds, and perpetuation of fraud through the corporate vehicle.

Title: Perpetual Real Estate Services, Inc. v. Michaelson Properties, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Virginia, Alexandria Division. .
Headnote: To pierce corporate veil under Virginia law, plaintiff need only show that corporation, as alter ego, dummy, or stooge, was used to disguise wrongs, to obscure fraud, or to conceal crime.

Title: Marett v. Professional Ins. Careers, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: To establish basis for disregarding corporate entity on ground that corporation is mere alter ego of individual, it must be shown that stockholder's disregard of corporate entity made him mere instrumentality for transaction of own affairs, that there is unity of interest in ownership so that separate personalities of corporate and owners do not exist, and that to adhere to doctrine of corporate entity would promote injustice or protect fraud.
Document Preview: Executive recruiting agency brought suit against a corporation to recover fee allegedly owed under recruiting contract.  The State Court, Cobb County, McDuff, J., directed verdict in part and jury returned verdict in favor of corporation but against partner who had acted for corporation.  Appeal was taken.  The Court of Appeals, Sognier, Chief Judge, held that: (1) question of whether evidence authorized piercing corporate veil as to individual partner should not have been submitted to jury even though corporation was not sufficiently capitalized to begin operations, absent any showing of fraud, and (2) absent any evidence other than agency president's self-serving testimony to support theory of individual liability, partner was entitled to directed verdict. Reversed with directions.

Title: Croxton v. Crowley Maritime Corp.

Title: U.S. v. Nagelberg
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.

Title: K.C. Roofing Center v. On Top Roofing, Inc.
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Western District.
Headnote: Court may pierce corporate veil or disregard separate corporate entity if separateness is used as subterfuge to defraud creditor.
Document Preview: Creditor brought action against corporation and shareholder, seeking to recover on corporate debt and to hold the shareholder personally liable.  The Circuit Court, Jackson County, John I. Moran, J., entered judgment in favor of creditor and pierced the corporate veil.  Shareholder appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Kennedy, J., held that: (1) the evidence supported the findings that the shareholder dominated the corporation's activities, and that he organized series of corporations when he became unable to pay one corporation's creditors and, therefore, the evidence supported piercing the corporate veil, and (2) evidence of the shareholder's activities with respect to the multiple corporations was relevant and admissible. Judgment affirmed.

Title: Ohio Bur. of Workers' Comp. v. Widenmeyer Elec. Co.
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Ninth District, Medina County.
Headnote: Although there is no precise test for piercing the corporate veil and imposing alter ego liability, corporate fiction should be disregarded when: domination and control over corporation by those to be held liable is so complete that corporation has no separate mind, will, or existence of its own; that domination and control was used to commit fraud or wrong or other dishonest or unjust act; and injury or unjust loss resulted to plaintiff from such control and wrong.

The Court of Appeals, Baird, J., held that: (1) trial court did not err in finding that second corporation was merely a continuation of first corporation, and in imposing successor liability upon second corporation, and (2) it was error to pierce corporate veil to hold officer and employee of first corporation personally liable for workers' compensation lien. Document Preview: Trustee for Chapter 11 corporate debtor brought suit against alleged principal of debtor, seeking to recover for alleged principal's use of debtor's monies for what were believed to be nonbusiness purposes.  The Bankruptcy Court, Letitia Z. Clark, J., held that: (1) bankruptcy trustee that had not sufficiently pled or proved he had standing to pursue cause of action to avoid transfer voidable by creditor holding unsecured claim was precluded from recovering by means of state law causes of action for breach of fiduciary duty, conversion, negligence, assumpsit, and money had and received, and (2) evidence supported finding that principal controlled corporate debtor and its finances and had intent to defraud in transactions in which principal intentionally used corporate funds for his and/or his family's personal benefit, thus supporting avoidance of such transfers as fraudulent. Judgment for trustee.

Title: Bergh v. Mills

The District Court, Uinta County, Robert B. Ranck, J., entered judgment for partner and motel, and defendants appealed.  The Supreme Court, Cardine, C.J., held that: (1) there was sufficient evidence to support the court's finding of fraud with respect to partner's investment in the corporation; (2) the defendant partnership was liable for the fraudulent acts of one of its partners; (3) the motel could not recover under a fraud theory; and (4) there was sufficient evidence to pierce the corporate veil. Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.

The Court of Appeals, Gee, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) finding that managers of gas company and its wholly owned affiliate had consented to independent oil producer's alleged conversion of affiliate's gas, by signing agreement to purchase oil producer's casinghead gas even though they suspected that producer had obtained gas by high-level perforation of gas formations to which affiliate held rights, was sufficiently supported by evidence, and (2) consent continued, at very latest, until plaintiffs filed suit against producer. Affirmed in part, reversed in part and remanded.

Milligan, J., held the corporation liable on three counts, and submitted to the jury the remaining two counts, which requested the court to pierce the corporate veil and hold the two individuals liable. Affirmed.

Headnote: In equity, the corporate entity may be disregarded and held to be the mere alter ego of a shareholder or shareholders in various circumstances where necessary to prevent fraud or other injustice.

Title: Maritime Ventures Intern., Inc. v. Caribbean Trading & Fidelity, Ltd.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: When individuals use corporation to perpetrate a fraud, or so dominate and disregard corporate form that corporation primarily transacts their personal business, court may pierce corporate veil and impose liability directly upon the individuals.

On motions to dismiss, the District Court, William C. Conner, J., held that: (1) evidence showed existence of binding charter party; (2) owner's allegations provided basis for exercise of subject-matter jurisdiction over claims against charter corporation's president; (3) arbitration agreement acted as waiver of immunity for purposes of subject-matter jurisdiction against country of St. Kitts-Nevis; (4) questions of fact precluded summary judgment on claims against charterer's officials, and country of St. Kitts-Nevis; and (5) owner was entitled to amend complaint to add joint venture claim. Motions to dismiss and motions for sanction denied except that motion to dismiss cause of action for fraud granted.

Title: U.S. v. Cohn
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: New York law permits a court to disregard corporate form whenever necessary to prevent a fraud or to achieve equity.
Document Preview: Internal Revenue Service brought action against corporation which owned townhouse and against law firm of which taxpayer had been a member to collect taxes and accrued interest.
